update.title: Sdf_reference_geometry

content.raw:
Changes to ign-math and SDF were described, but I didn't see anything about Gazebo. 

* Is the idea to parse all the transformations within SDF and keep the current interface with Gazebo? I'm afraid most information would be quickly lost in this case.

* What will the user see when they look at the pose from within Gazebo? Will there be an indication of the pose's frame? Or will the current behaviour be kept (in which case they will never be able to check if their SDF values were properly parsed)?

![pose.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/RgX9je/images/3606417985-pose.png)

* Will there be a `frame` field in the [pose message](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/6bef1d4ac015b321e77a492d229308fcbfb8b54b/gazebo/msgs/pose.proto)?

* How about poses in the physics library? For example, [Joint::anchorPose](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/6bef1d4ac015b321e77a492d229308fcbfb8b54b/gazebo/physics/Joint.hh?at=default#Joint.hh-648) will still always be wrt the child link?
content.html:
Changes to ign-math and SDF were described, but I didn't see anything about Gazebo.

  • Is the idea to parse all the transformations within SDF and keep the current interface with Gazebo? I'm afraid most information would be quickly lost in this case.

  • What will the user see when they look at the pose from within Gazebo? Will there be an indication of the pose's frame? Or will the current behaviour be kept (in which case they will never be able to check if their SDF values were properly parsed)?

  • Will there be a frame field in the pose message?

  • How about poses in the physics library? For example, Joint::anchorPose will still always be wrt the child link?

content.raw:
How will the frame names be handled? Do they need to be unique across all models? A nested model example:

~~~
<model name="model1">
  <frame name="f_model">
    <pose frame="world">1 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
  </frame>
  <pose frame="f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
  
  <model name="model2">
    <frame name="f_model">
      <pose frame="world">0 0 1 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <pose frame="f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

    <link name="link">
      <frame name="f_link">
        <pose frame="f_model">0 0 2 0 0 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <pose frame="f_link">0 1 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </link>
  </model>
   
  <model name="model3">
    <frame name="f_model">
      <pose frame="world">2 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <pose frame="f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

    <link name="link">
      <frame name="f_link">
        <pose frame="f_model">0 0 2 0 0 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <pose frame="f_link">0 1 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </link>
  </model>   

</model>
~~~

* SDF allows links within different models to have the same name, visuals within different links to have the same name and so on. Would this be supported for frames as well? When you say the definition of frames is independent of the hierarchy, I think there would be many collisions.

* Probably most models will be declared with a frame with respect to the world. What happens when they are nested into other models? Does the user need to expand the model and change that? (actually this might be a nested models question) My point here is that the concept of a "parent" frame might be handy - so the frame would be expressed with respect to whatever it is embedded into.
content.html:
How will the frame names be handled? Do they need to be unique across all models? A nested model example:

<model name="model1">
  <frame name="f_model">
    <pose frame="world">1 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
  </frame>
  <pose frame="f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

  <model name="model2">
    <frame name="f_model">
      <pose frame="world">0 0 1 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <pose frame="f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

    <link name="link">
      <frame name="f_link">
        <pose frame="f_model">0 0 2 0 0 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <pose frame="f_link">0 1 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </link>
  </model>

  <model name="model3">
    <frame name="f_model">
      <pose frame="world">2 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <pose frame="f_model">0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>

    <link name="link">
      <frame name="f_link">
        <pose frame="f_model">0 0 2 0 0 0</pose>
      </frame>
      <pose frame="f_link">0 1 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </link>
  </model>   

</model>

  • SDF allows links within different models to have the same name, visuals within different links to have the same name and so on. Would this be supported for frames as well? When you say the definition of frames is independent of the hierarchy, I think there would be many collisions.

  • Probably most models will be declared with a frame with respect to the world. What happens when they are nested into other models? Does the user need to expand the model and change that? (actually this might be a nested models question) My point here is that the concept of a "parent" frame might be handy - so the frame would be expressed with respect to whatever it is embedded into.

content.raw:
Would this function set a new parent for the graph and return true on success? 

Can the graph be broken apart into smaller graphs or combined with another graph into a new larger graph?
content.html:
Would this function set a new parent for the graph and return true on success?

Can the graph be broken apart into smaller graphs or combined with another graph into a new larger graph?

content.raw: Can you add a section about backward compatibility?
content.html: Can you add a section about backward compatibility?

content.raw: ok nevermind I see that this design document is only for SDF
content.html: ok nevermind I see that this design document is only for SDF

content.raw: We should also look at the design in [IHMC's simulator](http://www.ihmc.us/groups/scs/), since they use reference frames to define poses and vectors.
content.html: We should also look at the design in IHMC's simulator, since they use reference frames to define poses and vectors.

content.raw: Looks like anything in Gazebo that has a `pose` will require some changes to understand the new sdf `frame` element. Maybe describe those changes?
content.html: Looks like anything in Gazebo that has a pose will require some changes to understand the new sdf frame element. Maybe describe those changes?

content.raw: No it's not necessary. A snapshot is fine
content.html: No it's not necessary. A snapshot is fine

content.raw:
I did not envision the use of `FramesHierarchy` after parsing the SDF. This proposal only works for a "snapshot" of the information, as it is specified in the SDF. This could affect the way sdf state is saved and restored, and the ability to visualize frames in Gazebo. 

I suspect we would need a way to "connect" certain frames to joint angles and prismatic lengths. Do you think it should be necessary to keep track of the frames during simulation as well?
content.html:
I did not envision the use of FramesHierarchy after parsing the SDF. This proposal only works for a "snapshot" of the information, as it is specified in the SDF. This could affect the way sdf state is saved and restored, and the ability to visualize frames in Gazebo.

I suspect we would need a way to "connect" certain frames to joint angles and prismatic lengths. Do you think it should be necessary to keep track of the frames during simulation as well?

content.raw:
questions:

1. will `FramesHierarchy` be a singleton or something that lives throughout the life cycle of the simulation?

1. will `FramesHierarchy` track the pose of all entities at every iteration?
content.html:
questions:

  1. will FramesHierarchy be a singleton or something that lives throughout the life cycle of the simulation?

  2. will FramesHierarchy track the pose of all entities at every iteration?
